title: Britain's CRUMBLING roads are worse than NAMIBIA despite huge fuel tax
text:
Britain's CRUMBLING roads are worse than NAMIBIA despite huge fuel tax Britain's CRUMBLING roads are worse than NAMIBIA despite huge fuel tax BRITAIN’S roads are worse than those in many other developed nations even though we fork out the world’s highest tax on fuel, according to a new study. PUBLISHED: 12:42, Wed, Feb 22, 2017 | UPDATED: 12:59, Wed, Feb 22, 2017 GETTY Britain's road network as ranked 27th in the world 
BRITAIN’S roads are worse than those in many other developed nations even though we fork out the world’s highest tax on fuel, according to a new study. 
The Centre for Economics and Business Research (CEBR) ranked the UK’s road network 27th in the world, behind France, the US, Canada, Germany and Spain. 
Major roads are in a worse state than those of relatively poor countries such as Namibia and Ecuador. Related articles GETTY London's Tower Bridge was closed for several weeks last year for road repairs 
The report will anger campaigners who have long complained British drivers are forced to pay the world’s highest rates of tax on diesel and the fifth highest on petrol, amounting to £33billion each year. 
The CEBR criticised the government for splashing out the vast bulk of the transport budget on “eye-catching” rail projects such as the £56bn HS2 line linking London with the North and an upgrade of existing lines that is expected to cost more than £50 billion. 
But, despite throwing money at at the railways, MPs on the Commons Transport Committee admitted earlier this month that Britain’ rail franchising model is no longer fit for purpose, does not providing competition and is letting passengers down on a daily basis. GETTY Britain's motorists pay the highest fuel tax in the world With our road network such a snarling, constipated ruin, we wonder why pollution is at record levels? Quentin Wilson 
According to a national passenger survey run by watchdog Transport Focus, satisfaction with services has suffered a significant decline over the past year with commuters in the south-east particularly unhappy. 
Fare rises have easily outstripped wage inflation in the last decade but one in five passengers now expect a poor service and two million commuters see late trains and overcrowding as a normal part of everyday life. 
The roads report, commissioned by the FairFuelUK campaign, said rail investment is almost nine times that of road investment per mile, with £186,000 spent on rail infrastructure for every million miles of passenger travel in 2015 compared with £21,000 for roads. 
It said road upgrades deliver economic benefits that are 50 per cent higher. GETTY Britain’s roads are the most congested in western Europe The world's scariest roads Tue, November 10, 2015 Brace yourselves for the world's most scariest roads. From the highest to the windiest, these are sure to make your stomach turn. IG 1 of 16 Vehicles teeter on the edge of Yungas Road in Bolivia aka Death Road, which claims the lives of around 200 people every year 
A separate study by traffic consultancy Inrix found Britain’s roads are also the most congested in western Europe and London is the world’s seventh worst city for tailbacks, with vehicles reduced to 4mph at peak times. 
Motoring journalist and FairFuelUK spokesman Quentin Willson said: “These are truly shameful numbers. With our road network such a snarling, constipated ruin, we wonder why pollution is at record levels?” 
The Department for Transport said: “We are investing a record £23 billion to make the biggest improvements to our roads since the 1970s, making journeys faster, better and more reliable for everyone.” Related articles
